…and so even now so much is lost in translation, people who are very smart can just talk past each other without meaning to. Just a few notes b/c I’ve been reading Heidegger again after long absence based on intelligent spaces. @Athens_Stranger
…they also can’t build new words like Heidegger could do. All those esoteric concepts he developed when translated in English don’t look weird in German. They’re even pretty obvious in the original…

..,Heidegger’s exploration of Greek roots came naturally to him as native German speaker - he looked at those Greek words like he would look at a German word, taking it apart. English speakers can’t do this with their language, and this makes little sense to them…

…no one knows difference. Every word is just a concept, almost like a Chinese character. So the split b/w continental and Anglo philosophy has a lot of different causes - but one of them is this simple. The analysis of language operates differently b/w English and German…

…English mostly lost this organic quality a long time ago (Norman invasion and all that) and so this kind of analysis is unusual in Anglosphere. The words are imported, or built off foreign roots. Even if they’re organic, having so many foreign words means…

Heidegger did a lot of linguistic analysis to get at philosophical concepts. This is something a German would do, b/c the language is organic. You can look at one of those very long German words and know what it means - it’s just bunch of words thrown together..

7/…it’s a very watchable film, clearly influenced by the emerging Italian neo-realism. It also captures a divided Berlin before the wall went up. Recommended for entertainment and historical value.
6/…ultimately things turn out badly (no spoiler) for 2 of the 3 defectors. The third returns to East Berlin, to his girlfriend, and a friendly police officer encourages him to start his life over..

5/…even aspects of East German society come in for criticism. Westen culture (Brando) isn’t even criticized, actually lauded. Also the postwar nature of society is explored, with kids mentioning fathers killed in WW2 and an unexplored bomb found at a construction site..

4/…eventually several of the kids make off to West Berlin with aim of defecting. For all three of them this turns out badly, but not in a ham-fisted way. In very human ways that don’t directly criticize western capitalism…

3/…the police take an interest in them, are firm, but also indulgent, attempt to get them employment, improve their lives. One delinquent has a brother who has cleaned up his life and praises socialism…

2/…film revolves around a group of delinquent teenagers hanging out on street corner in East Berlin. They engage in petty crime, mostly avoid regular work. They listen to Western rock and roll, and one gal praises Marlon Brando as her ideal man…

Humor exists when something doesn’t come as expected, or is off in some way. And for some people there is a cultural limit, a sort of ‘no go zone.’ For others there isn’t much of a limit, and they will laugh at a lot of things that strike others as totally obscene.

Humor exists in different planes, and goes very dark for some folks. Kafka read the execution scene of ‘K’ from ‘The Trial’ to his friends, and couldn’t stop laughing. They didn’t think it was funny. There are layers of irony that are too deep for some people.

12/ Concluding note - this is about 2 hours of on your feet work. The rest of it is you doing whatever you want while it cooks. And this makes at least 8 servings. So if you’re a couple, this is gonna feed you for a while, justifying the time.
@BuckSexton One learns to cut corners in life…

11/ this is very good right away. But you can let rest overnight, and then take portion you want, place in sauce pan with a little wine and stock, and reheat. That’s what you see below. Serve with bread and green salad with a little fried/breaded goat cheese. Enjoy! https://t.co/WNYCtexJBr

10/ add in about half your breadcrumbs to top, cover pot, put back in oven for about 30m. Pull it, then top with remaining breadcrumbs. Put in oven uncovered, and cook for 30-40m, until you’ve got a little gold on crust. Then pull and let sit. https://t.co/grwPpcE0Lh

9/ pull at 90m, and remove your celery spice bundle and salt pork. While this is cooking, you take about 1/2 a baguette, shred it and put in food processor with 2 tbsp olive oil and a big handful of parsley and thyme. This will be your breadcrumbs. https://t.co/DxnBz5yhUM

8/ now add in your drained beans, 3 cups chicken stock and 1 cup of same wine. If beans aren’t covered, add a little more wine. Bring to simmer, then cover and put in oven at 300F for 90m. https://t.co/q4QiRk3Zos

7/ when soft, add in your diced garlic and tomato paste. Then add back your sausage, and about 2/3 cup white wine (I used reasonable Chardonnay). Deglaze pot, scrape up brown bits. Add in your celery bundle, drained can 14 oz tomatoes and salt pork back. https://t.co/nnoKbUfTNX

6/ Get your Dutch oven, drop a couple tbsp olive oil into it - get it hot. Then brown your sausage pieces. Pull, then do same thing with pork shoulder. Then add onion/carrot to pork shoulder, sweat them for a few minutes till soft. https://t.co/JUx0mk5wpb
5/ Boil the salt pork and sausage for about 5 minutes. Then pull, cut sausage into chunks. https://t.co/NHepmFRCMu

4/ other prep - small dice 2 carrots and and an onion. 6-7 medium cloves of garlic diced. Roughly a tbsp tomato paste. Also 2 sticks of celery - put a small of handful of fresh thyme sprigs, and 3 small bay leaves inside, then tie them together with twine. https://t.co/NlBi2cfBbY

3/ What else you need - 2 lbs pork shoulder cut into chunks, about same of sausage of your choice - fresh andouille that I got from local shop is good. You need 6 oz of salt pork. https://t.co/yWE3RqJrLu

2/ Night before you make this, you must soak 1 lb of white beans in cold water that covers them, and about a tbsp of salt - at least 12 hours - drain them when you’re ready to cook. https://t.co/DWMYHENBGZ

All large companies have this built-in protection. So keep this in mind if GOP Congress tries to get info from Facebook, Apple - whatever. They will never hand over the most sensitive stuff. They will provide a "privilege log" and explain that they've withheld it as 'privileged.'

So Vijaya Gadde wasn't just there as a censor - but as a lawyer to make sure that any communications concerning censorship conveyed "legal advice," and wouldn't be turned over in face of government investigation. But that's out the window now.

One reason companies have internal legal depts is to shield communications behind attorney-client privilege. So if govt subpoenas you re election interference, you hold back emails with lawyer cc'd on them. But if you own Twitter, you can just waive privilege, put it out there.

@annakhachiyan I had never heard Kubrick was mad, just a little reclusive and obsessive. There is a recorded interview of him floating around where he talks about his early life in NYC, playing chess in Washington Square, learning his film craft. Comes across as highly intelligent and normal.

@annakhachiyan Yes, the work could be seen as a little crazy. Why did he need to write Art of Fugue? But that sort of pulsation in his work didn’t mean he had to go around behaving badly, as Beethoven did, insulting everyone/losing friends and family - which is the crazy part filmmakers like.

Byron was supposedly ‘mad, bad and dangerous to know,’ which is why we know a lot about him. But Wordsworth was a better poet IMO, but fairly normal. Goethe kept his dangerous impulses under control in way Kleist couldn’t - and was a superior artist who didn’t kill himself.

It is not true that you must be crazy to be a creative genius. It happens, but is not necessary. But the crazy guys make for better biopics, so the notion spreads. Bach was probably GOAT, but he was very normal, industrious. And so there isn’t any ‘Amadeus’ about Bach.

This matters because people say things like we must confront Russia or China because look at what happened with Germany in 1914 or 1939. But even those conflicts weren’t inevitable. This is hindsight, and is often used to justify actions that will generate war now.

So if you read about the American Revolution for instance, one reads about the Stamp Act in light of the war, but this isn’t how the people at the time saw it. They didn’t think a war was coming. Most major wars can be seen through this lens.

When you read history, is good always to remember that the actors didn’t know how things would end. Seems obvious, but there is tendency to see everything as obvious and inevitable, then to overlook turning points.

@primalpoly My suspicion is that people either have the horsepower up front and can learn other languages, or they don't. For those who have the horsepower, learning language helps them reach their full potential. Like chess or learning piano would.

Another benefit is tyou learn to express things differently. It's not uncommon for multilingual people to draw on expressive capacity of one language to describe something in another, which can improve one's writing/level of expression. Finally - it's just fun and opens doors.

And some languages are harder than others. Someone who can learn Spanish may be incapable of learning Chinese. Some languages are "high IQ languages." If you are able to learn Chinese, the broader intellectual benefit is probably higher b/c you must work that much harder.
@blatterfurkunst People usually learn English grammar now in reverse, by learning a foreign language and comparing back. That's actually another benefit of learning some other language these days.

Fairly convinced that classical education based in learning Greek/Latin from young age was hugely beneficial for these reasons. Especially for speakers of analytic languages like English - synthetic language like Latin are so different that brain must really grind to pin it down.

Learning foreign language requires: 1) memorization of vocabulary; 2) understanding of grammatical structure, which rewires communication center of brain;  3) intense practice/perseverance. All 3 spill over, improve learning/habits everywhere else. So collapse in USA lamentable.

9/ I like to let this sit overnight and eat next day to let flavors blend. When you’re ready, serve over brown rice, add sliced green onion as garnish, and hit with tobasco if desired. Enjoy! https://t.co/wraazcYmiP

8/ once that’s done, add in your shredded chicken and your green onions. Hit it also with 1 tbsp apple cider vinegar, splashes of tobasco. Blend flavors and then add salt and pepper to taste. https://t.co/9KGAokmn0E
7/ when you’ve pulled the chicken, add in the sausage. Then add in your roux, whisking bit by bit to combine. Bring to light simmer, and cook/thicken for 20m. https://t.co/6jYEomhr6q

6/ once you’ve bloomed your spices in the vegetables, add 2 cups of stock - again, I used 1 chicken and 1 vegetable. Add your chicken thighs. Cook them for about 20m in simmering liquid. When internal temp is 165, pull them. Shred them when they cool. https://t.co/RTWDcN3UoQ

5/ while all this is going on, toast 6 ounces of flour in oven at 400 degrees for 40m. This will be your roux. When it’s nicely browned, pull, let it cool, then mix it with 2 cups of broth. I used half chicken and half vegetable. https://t.co/TTYNVXYuWp

4/ put a couple tbsps olive oil in Dutch oven. Then add your peppers, onions and celery. Cook till soft. Then add 1 tbsp paprika, diced garlic, chopped thyme, 1 tsp cayenne, 3 bay leaves, cranks of fresh salt and pepper. https://t.co/rqWH5PfNrM

12/..so American founders wanted to prevent officials from being able to do this - to keep justice behind closed doors, where it could become corrupt. But by turning trials into a media circus, we've basically done the same thing - prevented defendants from getting fair trial.

11/ In fact there is a great irony here. The reason trials are supposed to be public (meaning you can walk in and sit in the gallery during the trial) was that people in England were sometimes convicted in secret, and punished..

10/ Upshot is that these trials shouldn't be televised any longer. And juries should be very carefully picked in high publicity cases, and then sequestered from any news media. There is nothing in Constitution requiring TV cameras in courtroom.

9/..but maybe not - he might not even be sure, or he may have convinced himself after the fact. Point is the trial was completely tainted. First Amendment totally overwhelmed Chauvin's 6A right to fair trial...

8/..the smart set wanted to convict Chauvin based on the testimony of the doctor who claimed Floyd died by strangulation rather than drug overdose. Maybe, but even he had bias - he was given opportunity to be national hero, convict the evil cop. Maybe he was objective...

7/...this impacted everything that followed. Every juror was biased. Judge was biased. Witnesses probably misremembered things based on all the press they saw (eye witness testimony is notoriously unreliable and memory is easy to manipulate)..

6/..evidence objectively. Now consider how much worse this was for Chauvin. You have the press running an edited version of Chauvin with his knee on Floyd's neck 24/7. The full tape of what happened didn't come out till much later, after everyone had made up their minds..

5/ Today there are serious questions of his guilt. I don't want to go down that rabbit hole, only point out that he certainly didn't get a fair trial. He was convicted in the press in advance, and then the judge didn't even try to control his courtroom. Jurors couldn't examine..

4/..Hauptmann himself was a German immigrant at a time that Hitler was in power - so his accent did him no favors either. Lindbergh was a darling suffering a tragic loss. Hauptmann was inevitably convicted and quickly executed (yes, it was once possible to get this done fast)..

3/ In courtroom, Richard Hauptmann never received fair trial. Press was literally snapping pictures with huge flashes during testimony, yelling out questions to lawyers, judge, witnesses and Hauptmann himself. Was a circus...

2/ The original case that really brought out this tension was probably the Lindbergh kidnapping trial. Here you have celebrity pilot (Spirt of St Louis) who tragically loses baby. Right at this same time, broadcast media erupted in form of radio, and muckraking press was big..

1/ Short legal thread. There is tension b/w 1st Amendment right to free press and 6th Amendment right to fair trial. In most cases not problem b/c press ignores a trial. But consider Derek Chauvin. He was convicted before the trial ever started b/c press coverage. This isn't new.

16/...that originates in Haydn. We will see more of Haydn as we work through the Opus 18 quartets in general. Some time in coming days we will move to the Second Movement of Op. 18, no. 1 - consider this an appetizer.

15/ Final historical point I would like to make about this movement is that it relies somewhat on Haydn. Beethoven is original here, but the idea of taking a simple motive built out of a few pitches, and working every permutation out so that you've got a movement...
14/...then you will hear the key transition. This will also make the wild modulations in the Development more interesting and understandable.

13/ In the exposition, you have the initial theme group, then some transitional music as you move from F Major to C (the dominant), and then a new theme group. You won't hear this first time through. But if you listen to Expo, then the Recap (where both themes are in F)...

12/ I recommend listening to the entire 9 minutes, then going back and breaking it down if you want to hear the structure better. The entire movement is based on a turn motive, which opens the movement. You will hear it, and variations of it, over 100 times.

11/ The trick is that in the recap both themes appear in the home key, which here is F Major. Time breakdown:

0:00 - 2:25 - Exposition
2:25 - 5:10 - Exposition Repeat 
5:10 - 6:00 - Development
6:00 - 8:20 - Recap
8:20 - 8:50 - Coda - some concluding music.

10/ In a Sonata form, you have an exposition, which introduces generally 2 major themes. Then a development section, which plays with the themes in various ways. Then a recap, where the first two themes reappear.

9/ First timing. On the above, you want to listen to the up through 8:50. That's the first moment of the quartet, which is in Sonata form. What's that? It's the premier classical era form that arose out of opera. Idea is to have a couple different voices interact, like in a duet.
